title: Data highlighting
description:
Directly specifies numerical values in
the headline
ExampleTxt: There have been 7m-13m excess deaths worldwide during the pandem

title: Stating an issue
description:
Not directly displaying data
but using dataset or event names
ExampleTxt: Covid in the UK cases, deaths and vaccinations – the latest numbers

title: Making an evaluation or Judgment
description: Stating a finding from the data or an identified issue
ExampleTxt: Hospital treatment is still a waiting game

title: Asking a question
description: Using the question as the title directly
ExampleTxt: Does Gen Z spend too much time on social media?

title: Sensationalism
description: Employs exaggerated and dramatic language to capture attention
ExampleTxt: The global stagflation shock of 2022.

title: Textal lead
description: Introducing the article’s content through text
ExampleTxt: The latest updates on coronavirus cases, deaths and hospitalisations, using the best available national data.

title: Image lead
description:
Using images, photographs, or a combination of visuals
and data visualizations to represent the article’s content
ExampleTxt: Like the article from Financial Times

title: Giving the link directly
description: Giving a clickable link (URL) to the database directly
ExampleTxt: Data from Effis shows that as of 23 July, just over 515,000 hectares (1.27m acres) of land had been burned across EU countries...

title: Mentioning the data source
description: Citing the name of the institute/data report/website without giving a link (URL)
ExampleTxt: The NHS has succeeded in eliminating two-year waits, but in future the length of delays in treatment looks set to creep up again.

title: Inverted pyramid
description: The inverted pyramid in journalism refers to a story structure where the most important information (or what might even be considered the conclusion) is presented first. The who, what, when, where and why appear at the start of a story, followed by supporting details and background information.
ExampleTxt: Boris Johnson has resigned as Conservative leader after nearly three years in Downing Street. After taking the helm in July 2019 following Theresa May鈥檚 resignation, Johnson secured a large Conservative majority in parliament after calling a snap general election in December that year...

title: Freytag’s pyramid
description: Based on the four major narrative categories: Establisher (E), Initial (I), Peak (P), and Release (R))

title: Drilling-down
description: Guide the reader from a wide view to a focused view.
ExampleTxt: When Covid-19 hit Georgia in March 2020, the Atlanta Breakfast Club closed its doors to in-person dining for weeks on end...general managers and other staff at a time of fierce competition for workers in one of the tightest labour markets in the US.

title: Compositing
description: The Compositing structure centers on a unifying theme, presenting various pieces of information in either a complementary or parallel fashion to create a comprehensive view. Each section independently explains an aspect of the topic. It may also take the form of a question-and-answer format, where questions are used as titles for subsections.
ExampleTxt: Each module independently explains a portion of the theme,  Contains structures such as Kabob, the Stack of Blocks......

title: Stating the value
description:
Stating the
value simply presents the values or the change of the value.
ExampleTxt: Uber spans about 1,200 locations, covering 10,000 towns and cities worldwide.

title: Change over time
description: Describing the trend and comparison of values at different times.
ExampleTxt: By July 2022, the burned area of the EU is 515,000 hectares, which is four times the estimated level recorded since 2006.

title: Contrasting
description:
Comparing the
data, such as contrasting a whole with its parts or present rankings.
ExampleTxt: Britain is ranked only 109th for the proportion of budget it spends on education...

title: Comparing between regions
description:
Comparing data
values across different geographical areas.
ExampleTxt: In Wales, 15 per cent of the population were aged 65 and over in 1981 - the same as London — but that rose to 21.3 per cent in 2021.

title: Data notables
description: Focuses on specific values such as outliers and extrema
ExampleTxt: ...the town's water system has exceeded the federal legal nitrate limit by 15 times....

title: Basic description
description: Presenting a rough summary of the content, describing a high-level message
ExampleTxt: As the final votes are counted, heavy Conservative losses are tempered by a mixed picture for Labour while Lib Dems and the Greens perform well. The SNP continues to dominate in Scotland and Plaid Cymru gain seats in their heartlands and beyond.

title: Citing the authority
description: Involves referencing government or academic reports, as well as quoting experts to enhance the article’s credibility
ExampleTxt: ....than most other rich countries,”said Max Lawson, head of inequality policy at Oxfam International..

title: Co-relation and causality
description: Putting data into context, reveals the co-relation of events, and explains reasons
ExampleTxt: ...these indicators have important implications for the level of inequality: taxation, social spending in sectors such as health...

title: Domain knowledge
description: To elaborate on co-relation or causality, creators may extend to explaining concepts in specific domain knowledge
ExampleTxt: EPA stipulates that the nitrate content per liter of water is 10 mg, but it is often exceeded. This standard is designed to prevent the fetus from getting enough oxygen.

title: Adding detailed data
description: Providing specific examples or more in-depth data.
ExampleTxt: In the Guardian report Europe’s record summer of heat and fires – visualized, special cases such as France and Spain were introduced for high-temperature areas in Europe.

title: Inferences
description:
Providing appropriate inferences according
to the data.
ExampleTxt: This discrepancy mirrors a global trend: low-income countries tend to have more progressive tax structures...

title: Interpretation
description: Illustrate links in the development of things
ExampleTxt: Despite the additional disruption caused by Brexit, developed economies around the world are dealing with similar problems.

title: Citing different viewpoints
description: Present different opinions by citing perspectives from different entities.
ExampleTxt: Others, however, back the government’s decision to unlock now.

title: Adding emotional factors
description: Refers to the intentional inclusion of emotionally resonant elements in the article to elicit empathy from readers.
ExampleTxt: She is on 20mg of morphine a day to manage the pain, yet regularly wakes in the night.

title: Data source description
description: Provide information about the issuing organization, sample method, and whether the data is preprocessed or filtered for certain reasons.
ExampleTxt: The current estimate of the number of people infected with the new crown in the UK is based on NHS household surveys and test samples. Times are posted weekly.

title: Presenting a different statistic method
description: Involves the use of novel statistical approaches to reveal insights that may not be apparent using conventional methods of data analysis.
ExampleTxt: We used statistical patterns to create baselines... Our materials include databases from Berkeley collaborations and datasets created by Karlinsky et al....

title: Data analysis
description: Present the process of analyzing the data, interpreting the statistics, and drawing conclusions.
ExampleTxt: Our COVID-19 tracking shows that Western European countries have been slow to the vaccine in early 2021, leading to an increase in excess mortality. But by June the mortality rate in the region has normalized

title: Predicting the future trend
description: Predict the future trend of an event based on the current data.
ExampleTxt: By 2050, scientists expect new items to have the same carbon timestamp as medieval items.

title: Describing the content of the visualization
description: Providing an interpretation or summary of what the data visualization is presented
ExampleTxt: In the table below, you can check the number of deaths in the location.

title: Actions
description: Focuses on detailing the actions that have been taken or are recommended to be taken in light of the data-driven findings.
ExampleTxt: ... the areas most affected by the disaster have announced a ban on the use of hoses...

title: Linking to external references
description: Include links to other articles in the text as references.
ExampleTxt: .. even as Downing Street staff were breaking the government’s own lockdown rules by throwing parties.(link to article: Boris Johnson’s Partygate remorse lasts all of 30 seconds)

title: Summarize
description: Conclude from the pre-mentioned data and arguments as a take-home message of a section or the entire article.
ExampleTxt: The UK’s lack of investment in education and relatively low tax rates have created a highly unequal society in which the poor are “often unable to cover living costs”,...

title: Photo
description: Using Photographs in Articles
ExampleTxt: A satellite image of the UK taken on 10 August 2022 shows swathes of scorched brown.?Photograph: Met Office/Crown copyright/PA

title: Illustration
description: Using illustrations in Articles
ExampleTxt: Financial Times news article "High UK inflation hits sales, confidence and activity" uses illustrations as separators between paragraphs.

title: Data highlighting
description: Refering to the data or describe changes in data directly
ExampleTxt: While three in four people in rich countries are vaccinated against Covid, just over one in seven is in poor countries

title: Stating an issue
description: Giving an overview by stating the topic or the scope of the investigation without showing the data directly
ExampleTxt: UK: people in the hospital with coronavirus each day

title: Making an evaluation or judgment
description: Stating a finding from the data or an identified issue
ExampleTxt: The big wait

title: Asking a question
description: Using the question as the title directly
ExampleTxt: Who-is and isn't vaccinated?

title: Line chart
description: A line chart (aka line plot, line graph) uses points connected by line segments from left to right to demonstrate changes in value. The standard way to show a changing time series.
ExampleTxt: In the past decade, there has been record...

title: Bar chart
description: A bar chart or bar graph is a chart or graph that presents categorical data with rectangular bars with heights or lengths proportional to the values that they represent.Columns work well for showing change over time - but usually best with only one series of data at a time.
ExampleTxt: Who is-and isn't-vaccinated

title: Table
description: A table chart is a means of arranging data in rows and columns.
ExampleTxt: Oxfam ranking 2017

title: Small multiple
description: A small multiple is a data visualization that consists of multiple charts arranged in a grid. This makes it easy to compare the entirety of the data. They are also known as trellis, lattice, grid, and panel charts.
ExampleTxt: Weekly death rates, US

title: Combined charts
description: The top and bottom of the chart are combined to jointly display the data content in a certain direction.
ExampleTxt: New reported cases

title: Map
description: A diagram or collection of data showing the spatial distribution of something or the relative positions of its components.
ExampleTxt: US covid map

title: Treemap
description: Treemap visualizations are space-efficient displays of large structured datasets: contiguous shapes are organized according to their hierarchy or categorization.Use for hierarchical part-to-whole relationships
ExampleTxt: Who Has The Most Historical Responsibility for Climate Change?

title: Stacked chart
description: This type of graph (sometimes called a stream graph) depicts aggregate patterns and often supports drill-down into a subset of individual series.
ExampleTxt: Europe and Americans have record the most cases throughout the pandamic

title: Dumbell chart/Slope
description: Perfect for showing how ranks have changed over time or vary between categories.
ExampleTxt: More people are living without sex

title: Pictogram
description: Excellent solution in some instances – use only with whole numbers (do not slice off an arm to represent a decimal).
ExampleTxt: Machine Politics: How America casts and counts its votes

title: Scatter plot
description: The standard way to show the relationship between two continuous variables, each of which has its own axis.
ExampleTxt: Wealthy countries have vaccinated far more people against Covid than poorer ones

title: Bubble
description: Like a scatterplot, but adds additional detail by sizing the circles according to a third variable.
ExampleTxt: Friendship across class lines may boost social mobility and decrease poverty

title: Other visual representation
description: For example: grid charts, heat maps,  matrix diagram, violin plots, timeline, Sankey diagram, and illustrations....
ExampleTxt: Europe imported 108 bcm of LNG in 2021. To hit its target of replacing Russian gas it will need to secure most of the viable destination-free LNG

title: Mentioning the data source
description: Specifying the data source or give a link (URL) to the data source.
ExampleTxt: Data: data.gov.uk

title: Visualization attribution
description: Describing the source of the visualization.
ExampleTxt: Guardian Graphic

title: Scope of data collection
description: Expaining the visual encoding or statistics in the chart.
ExampleTxt: Note: Charts show 14-day case averages, and the frequency of variants among cases is an estimate. Sequencing rates can reflect localized trends based on testing from a particular region or hospital. Charts show the latest available data, which may be lagged and may change as additional sequences are completed. Recent data is based on the smallest samples and is especially likely to change.

title: Describing the content of the visualization
description: Describing the trend, particular values of the data.
ExampleTxt: NHS England waiting list for treatment. The NHS is prioritizing very long waits, yet the overall list continues to grow

title: Additional information
description: Providing extra information that is not shown in the chart to further supplement the chart
ExampleTxt: Note: Time periods of BA.4 and BA.5 becoming dominant are estimates.

title: Numerical annotations
description: Represent the most prevalent category, encompassing numerical value near its visual representation.

title: Threshold annotations
description:
Delineate intervals or
values with specific significance.
ExampleTxt:
Delineate intervals or
values with specific significance.

title: Textual annotations
description: A text annotation within the plot area that provides additional context about the data or help orient the viewer by explaining the choice of scale or range.
ExampleTxt: UK: more than 40 houses destroyed in London after grass fires spread in several areas

title: Visual annotations
description: Refer to the provision of supplementary information through interactive tooltips and enhanced graphical imagery.
ExampleTxt: Adding auxiliary charts in the annotation for supplementary explanation/explanation.

title: Inspecting
description: Show the specifics of the data [hover line graph,hover line graph dot, hover map]
ExampleTxt: hover or click an element to see a tooltip with more information

title: Selecting
description: Mark something to keep track of it [click line graph, click line graph dot, click map, click list label],  and [click list checkbox]
ExampleTxt: Highlight elements to keep track of it in an animated graph

title: Zooming
description: Show me more or less detail [zoom in or out inside a map view to adjust level of abstraction]
ExampleTxt: Zoom in or out inside a map view to adjust the level of abstraction

title: Exploring
description: Show something else, [click query-button]
ExampleTxt: Show specifics based on the user's input/ query

title: Scrollytelling
description: Scrollytelling is one such emerging approach where dynamic updates to the article content are triggered by scrolling
ExampleTxt: Click on a stepper button to be guided to the next part of the story

title: Connecting
description: Show related items [hover list]
ExampleTxt: Click on one element and highlight all similar elements for comparison

title: Other
description: For example: Game; website links ......
ExampleTxt: The interactive modes of games may include various activities such as moving, jumping, attacking, dialogue, puzzle-solving, trading, etc. Examples relevant to this include articles like "What will it be like when we go back to the office?" by Reuters.

title: Data video
description: Combining data visualizations, animations, and audio narrations
ExampleTxt: Wherein information is conveyed as animated visual narratives with data visualizations

title: Complementary Video
description: Providing additional information to enhance the the topic beyond the data, with background information, interviews, expert opinions, and related coverage.
ExampleTxt: Examples relevant to this include articles like "The Queen’s 70-year reign in 10 charts " by Financial Times.
